journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Brownian motion and thermophoresis effects on natural convection of alumina–water nanofluid

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad Reza Haghgoo, Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Tabriz, Tabriz 5166616471, Iran. Email: haghgoo.reza87@ms.tabrizu.ac.ir

abstract.p: In this article a ‘two-component four-equation non-homogeneous equilibrium’ model has been adopted to accurately simulate the process of natural convection of Al2O3–water nanofluid inside a vertical square cavity. The aforementioned model considers conservation equation of nanoparticles which is highly coupled to other equations (mass, momentum, and energy equations for nanofluid) and includes the effects of Brownian motion and thermophoresis as the two most important mechanisms of slip velocity in laminar flow. The distribution of nanoparticles volume fraction is obtained by solving these four equations simultaneously. Renewing the effective properties of nanofluid from the nanoparticles, volume fraction distribution is another advantage of this model. Numerical results are in good agreement with published experimental data and emphasize that the use of the nanofluid for natural convection heat transfer enhancement in enclosure is impracticable for the studied range of solid volume fraction (1%≤φ0≤3%). Also, heat transfer rate decreases with an increase in nanoparticle volume fraction.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Nanofluids are engineered colloids composed of nanometer-sized particles suspended in traditional heat transfer fluids such as water, oil, and ethylene glycol. As nanoparticles are so small, they remain in suspension almost indefinitely and have less chance of sedimentation.1 Having remarkable increased thermal conductivity relative to the ordinary fluids which can be achieved even at low volume fraction of nanoparticles, nanofluids have attracted the attention of the heat transfer community.2–5 Recently various attempts have been made to explain the enhancement of nanofluid thermal conductivity. Researcher have attributed it to several factors such as the Brownian motion of the particles, the molecular-level layering of the liquid at the liquid–particle interface, the ballistic nature of heat transport in nanoparticles, the effect of clustering of nanoparticles,6 increase of particle–fluid contact surface, and interactions between particles.7,8 Experimental and numerical results show that in force convection the convective heat transfer coefficient increases by increasing particles volume fraction, for a given Reynolds number.9–11

Unlike forced convection, experimental results show that in buoyancy-driven flows, heat transfer coefficient decreases by increasing the nanoparticles volume fraction.12–16 For natural and mixed convection very few numerical studies have been carried out.

Khanafer et al.17 studied numerically natural convection of nanofluid inside a two-dimensional enclosure. They concluded that the heat transfer rate increases with nanoparticles volume fraction for a given Grashof number. Abu-Nada et al.18 studied natural convection in horizontal annuli modeling different nanofluids and showed an augmentation of the heat transfer. Ho et al.19 showed that the Nusselt number of natural convection in square enclosure increases by increasing nanoparticles volume fraction. Hwang et al.20 investigated thermal characteristics of natural convection in a rectangular cavity. They showed that using Pak and Cho’s21 model, the heat transfer coefficient decreases relative to the base fluid while using Einstein’s22 model gives opposite results. Santra et al.23 investigated the behavior of heat transfer in laminar natural convection inside a differentially heated square cavity. They solved non-Newtonian fluid’s transport equations and observed that heat transfer decreases with an increase in nanoparticles volume fraction for a particular Ra. Abouali and Falahatpisheh24 studied natural convection of a nanofluid in vertical annuli. They showed the Nusselt number decreases by increasing nanoparticles volume fraction. Almost all of these researchers assumed that nanofluids behaved as the common pure fluid. In other words, they used single-phase homogenous model according to which both the fluid phase and particles are in a thermal equilibrium condition and flow with the same velocity. This model differs from conventional pure fluid model only in the fluid properties where the effective properties which are obtained from the theoretical models or experimental data are used instead.

Kuznetsov and Nield25 studied natural convection of a nanofluid past a vertical plate. They used a similarity solution and claimed that ‘the reduced Nusselt number is a decreasing function of each buoyancy-ratio number, Brownian motion number and thermophoresis number’. Pakravan and Yaghoubi26 investigated theoretically the combined thermophoresis, Brownian motion, and Dufour effects on natural convection of nanofluids.

Another proposed approach is two phase mixture model in which the nanofluid is considered to be a single fluid with two phases, where the coupling between them is strong. But each phase has its own velocity and within any computational cell there exists a certain volume fraction of each phase.27

Additionally, some researchers have used discrete-phase approach for simulating nanofluids.28–30 This model describes the continuous phase flow field by Eulerian approach and the nanoparticle movement by Lagrangian trajectory.

However in this article, a third approach (Buongiorno’s two-component non-homogeneous approach31) has been employed to accurately simulate the process of natural convection of Al2O3–water nanofluid inside a vertical square cavity.

In this approach, the transport equations of nanofluid are solved along with the conservation equation for nanoparticles. The aforementioned equation is highly coupled to other equations (mass, momentum, and energy equations for nanofluid) and includes the effects of Brownian motion and thermophoresis as the two most important mechanisms of slip velocity in laminar flow. The distribution of nanoparticles volume fraction is obtained by solving these four equations simultaneously. Renewing the effective properties of the nanofluid from the volume fraction distribution is another advantage of this model.

sec.title: Problem statement
sec.p:
Two-dimensional vertical square enclosure (25 × 25 mm2) is considered, as shown in Figure 1. The top and bottom horizontal walls have been considered adiabatic while the two sidewalls are maintained at constant temperature TH and TC. The nanofluid is assumed to be Al2O3–water with the averaged diameter, dp, of the alumina particles equal to 33 nm.32 The nanofluid and flow in the enclosure are regarded as Newtonian incompressible and laminar, respectively (the Newtonian behavior was experimentally confirmed for nanoparticles volume fraction less than 4% by Putra et al.12). Figure 1.
Geometry of the problem.

sec.title: Governing equations and boundary conditions
sec.p: As emphasized before the conservation equation for nanoparticles in this model is highly coupled to other equations and they must be solved simultaneously.

This equation (the nanoparticles’ conservation equation) in steady state can be written as (1)∇.(φVnf)=-1ρp∇.(JP) where φ and ρp are volume fraction and density of nanoparticles, respectively, and JP the nanoparticles’ diffusion mass flux relative to the nanofluid velocity. As mentioned in Buongiorno,31 the two most important mechanisms of slip velocity in laminar flow are thermophoresis and Brownian motion. So the nanoparticles flux is a combination of these effects (2)JP=-DB∇φ-DT∇T where DB and DT are the Brownian motion and thermophoresis coefficients, respectively, which are defined as31,33 (3)DB=ρpkBT3πμfdp (4)DT=φSTρpρfμfT where kB,dp, and ST are Boltzman constant, nanoparticles diameter, and thermophoresis parameter, respectively.
The effective density can be estimated as (5)ρnf=φρp+(1-φ)ρf

By applying Boussinesq approximation to the base fluid (ρf), the specific weight (ρg) can be written as34,35 (6)(ρg)nf={φρp+(1-φ)⌊ρf0(1-β(T-T0))⌋}g Where T0 is the reference temperature, ρf0 the base fluid density at the reference temperature, and β the volumetric coefficient of thermal expansion of the base fluid.

The remainder of governing equations for nanofluid in steady state can be expressed as (7)∂u∂x+∂v∂y=0 (8)ρf0(u∂u∂x+v∂u∂y)=-∂p∂x+∂∂x(2μnf∂u∂x) +∂∂y(μnf(∂u∂y+∂v∂x)) (9)ρf0(u∂v∂x+v∂v∂y)=-∂p∂y+∂∂x(μnf(∂u∂y+∂v∂x)) +∂∂y(2μnf∂v∂y)-{φρp+(1-φ) [ρf0(1-β(T-T0))]}g (10)(ρCp)nf(u∂T∂x+v∂T∂y)=∂∂x(knf∂T∂x)+∂∂y(knf∂T∂y)

Assuming that the suspension is dilute (φ0 < 0.04) and since (T − T0) < 10 K and β is in the order of 10−4, the right-hand side of equation (9), after being linearized by neglecting the term φρf0β(T-T0)g, for simplicity in numerical calculations can be rewritten as (11)ρf0(u∂v∂x+v∂v∂y)=-∂p∂y+∂∂x(μnf(∂u∂y+∂v∂x)) +∂∂y(2μnf∂v∂y)-{φ0ρp+(1-φ0)ρf0 -ρf0β(T-T0)+(ρp-ρf0)(φ-φ0)}g where φ0 is the value of φ at reference state. Heat capacitance of the nanofluid can be written as (12)(ρCp)nf=(1-φ)(ρCp)f+φ(ρCp)p
The Maxwell36 model is used to determine the effective thermal conductivity of the nanofluid (13)knfkf=1+3(kp/kf-1)φ(kp/kf+2)-(kp/kf-1)φ

Since the presented numerical results have been validated against experimental data given by Ho et al.,32 the experimental correlation proposed by them has been adopted to calculate the viscosity of the nanofluid which is in good agreement with their experimental measurements (14)μnfμf=1+4.93φ+222.4φ2

Boundary conditions are as follows
Left wall: Jp=0,u=v=0,T=TH
Right wall: Jp=0,u=v=0,T=TC
Top wall: JP=0,u=v=0,∂T∂y=0
Bottom wall: JP=0,u=v=0,∂T∂y=0

Having the converged solution, the average Nusselt number for the hot wall can be calculated as (15)Nu¯nf=h¯nfWknf where W (characteristic length) is the width of the cavity and h¯nf the surface-averaged heat transfer coefficient which can be calculated as (16)h¯nf=q″HTH-TC where q″ is the steady state surface-averaged heat flux. Based on the temperature difference and the characteristic length of the enclosure, the Rayleigh number is determined as (17)Ranf=gCp,nfβnfρnf2(TH-TC)W3knfμnf

sec.title: Numerical approach and validation
sec.p: The set of coupled differential equations has been discretized by a control volume technique using a second-order upwind method. The SIMPLE algorithm was introduced for the velocity–pressure coupling. For convergence, under-relaxation technique has been employed. To check the convergence, the mass residue of each control volume has been calculated and the maximum value has been used to check the convergence. The convergence limit has been set to 10−3 which seems reasonable regarding the complexity of the problem at hand.

Several grid distributions have been examined to insure that the estimated results are grid independent. As presented in Table 1, increasing the grid numbers does not change significantly the vertical velocity and temperature at the mentioned point. Therefore, the computational domain has been divided into 250 × 250 non-uniform grids which is finer at the boundaries. Table 1.
Grid independent test (ΔT=2K φ0=0.01 x/W=0.008, y/W=0.5).
Number of nodes T(K) Vy(m/s)
150×150 300.936 2.248×10-4
200×200 300.937 2.262×10-4
250×250 300.937 2.274×10-4
300×300 300.937 2.276×10-4

Numerical results are validated against published experimental data on natural convection of alumina–water nanofluid done by Ho et al.32 Figure 2 shows the ratio of predicted heat transfer coefficient to experimental heat transfer coefficient, hnf,pred/hnf,expt and the mean average error (MAE) which is defined as (18)MAE(hnf)=1M∑|hnf,expt-hnf,pred|hnf,expt×100% where M is the number of data points. This figure also shows that the numerical estimated values agree well with those of experimental data with the MAE(hnf) being 6.2% and 5.8% for reference solid volume fraction of 1% and 3%, respectively. Figure 2.
Ratio of predicted heat transfer coefficient to experimental heat transfer coefficient versus temperature difference across the enclosure.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Numerical analysis of natural convection of Al2O3–water nanofluid in a square vertical cavity has been performed using the ‘two-component four-equation non-homogeneous equilibrium’ model. The reference temperature at which all thermophysical properties of different phases are calculated, has been considered to be 300 K26 (Table 2). Table 2.
Thermophysical properties of different phases at 300 K.26
Property Water Al2O3
ρ(kg/m3) 997.1 3970
Cp(J/kg K) 4179 765
k(W/m K) 0.613 40
β(K-1) 0.000267 0.00000846
μ(kg/m s) 0.000855 –

The nanoparticles averaged diameter is 33 nm in this study. The value of thermophoresis parameter (ST) in equation (4) has been extracted by comparing presented numerical results and previously published experimental data. For nanoparticles, this parameter has not ever been reported in the literature. However for large size particles, ST is a function of base fluid and particles’ thermal conductivities only. Therefore, it is a good approximation for this study to treat it as a constant coefficient. It was found that ST=0.018 for φ0=0.01 and ST=0.01 for φ0=0.03 give the best agreement between experimental data and numerical results for the problem at hand.

Figure 3 shows the profiles of vertical velocities at mid-height of the cavity for 0≤x≤0.025 and for ΔT=2K. It is observed that, the value of maximum velocity decreases by increasing φ0. It seems that, as φ0 increases, the viscosity and density of the nanofluid increases. As a result the effect of buoyancy decreases, causing the vertical velocity to decrease with an increase in φ0. Figure 3.
Profiles of vertical velocities at mid-height of the cavity for ΔT=2K and various particle fractions.

The isotherms for φ0=0%,1%, and 3%, for ΔT=2K, have been shown in Figure 4. It is observed that the thermal boundary layer gets thicker due to an increase in diffusive heat transfer which in turn results from an increase in φ0. Figure 4.
Isotherms for ΔT=2K and for: (a) φ0=0; (b) φ0=0.01; and (c) φ0=0.03.

The use of the aforementioned approach provides significant information on the nanoparticles distribution at the cavity. Figure 5 shows contour plots of nanoparticle volume fraction for φ0=0.01, for various temperature differences. By increasing temperature difference, the thermophoresis effect becomes more significant, causing the range of concentration variation to get broader, as shown. The results for φ0=0.03 follow the same pattern. Furthermore, as the nanoparticles distribution has been found to be non-uniform, the use of single-phase method does not seem reasonable for modeling the present problem. Figure 5.
Contours of nanoparticles distribution for ϕ0=0.01 and for: (a) ΔT=2K; (b) ΔT=6K; and (c) ΔT=8K.

Nanoparticles migrate from the hot wall to the cold wall due to the thermophoresis effect. This phenomenon leads to the formation of a thin film of low-φ nanofluid near the hot wall and a thin film of high-φ nanofluid near the cold wall. As expected, the free convection along the sidewalls induces a clockwise circulation inside the cavity. Therefore, a portion of low-φ nanofluid near the hot wall is pushed upward and forms a less-concentrated region near the top wall. Exactly the same phenomenon leads to the formation of a more-concentrated region near the bottom wall.

Since the density of nanoparticles is higher than the base fluid, the less-concentrated top region is less dense than the central region while the more-concentrated bottom region is denser than the central region. As a result, these two regions are trapped in their positions and become incapable of circulating, therefore separate from the bulk flow. That is why the presence of nanoparticles in the base fluid has made the streamlines be closer to each other in comparison with those of pure fluid, as can be seen in Figure 6(a) to (c). The less effective space for the nanofluid to circulate in the cavity, the less heat transfers. Figure 6.
Streamlines for ΔT=2K and for: (a) pure fluid; (b) φ0=0.01; and (c) φ0=0.03.

It is worth mentioning that the use of the aforementioned model has revealed the formation of two vortices near the top right-hand and bottom left-hand corners of the cavity, as shown in Figure 6(b) and (c), while the single-phase approach does not show the existence of such vortices (Figure 6(a)). Formation of these vortices can be attributed to opposite effects of buoyancy-induced movement and central clockwise circulation of nanofluid inside the cavity.

Having been separated from the circulating bulk flow, the regions near the top and bottom walls experience much less convection heat transfer. This, in turn, causes the temperature in the aforementioned regions to be nearly uniform. Moreover, increasing φ0 results in an increase in the thickness of these regions, as shown in Figure 7 in which temperature profiles at x=0.0125 for 0≤y≤0.025 and ΔT=2K have been presented for various nanoparticles volume fraction. Figure 7.
Temperature profiles at x=0.0125 for various temperature differences across the enclosures and ΔT=2K.

Figure 8 shows the numerical results for the ratio of average nanofluid heat transfer coefficient to the base fluid heat transfer coefficient, h¯nf/h¯f, versus the temperature difference, ΔT=TH-TC. It reveals that the presence of nanoparticles deteriorates the natural convection heat transfer. Figure 8.
Ratio of nanofluid heat transfer coefficient to the base fluid heat transfer coefficient for various temperature differences across the enclosures.

Figure 9 depicts the variation of average Nusselt number Nu¯nf as a function of Rayleigh number Ranf. It shows that for the nanofluid of fixed nanoparticles volume fraction, the average Nusselt number increases with Rayleigh number. Here the Rayleigh number has been increased by imposing larger temperature differences across the cavity. Figure 9.
Variation of average Nusselt number with the Rayleigh number for Al2O3–water nanofluid containing various particle fractions.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study effects of Brownian motion and thermophoresis are investigated numerically on the natural convection heat transfer of alumina–water nanofluid in a square vertical cavity using the ‘two-component four-equation non-homogeneous equilibrium’ model. Numerical results are in good agreement with experimental data and emphasize that: the use of nanofluid for natural convection heat transfer enhancement in enclosure is impracticable for the studied range of solid volume fraction (1%≤φ0≤3%). Also, heat transfer rate decreases with an increase in nanoparticles volume fraction.

Despite the fact that the effective thermal conductivity increases remarkably by injecting nanoparticles to the base fluid, it is recommended not to use them in the studied range of volume fraction (1%≤φ0≤3%) in such a natural convection process. That is because of heat transfer reduction due to decrease of effective space for heat transfer, which in turn, is the consequence of the presence of nanoparticles. To put it another way, the non-uniformity of nanoparticles distribution and crucial conclusions drawn by that imply that the use of single-phase homogeneous method does not seem reasonable for modeling this class of natural convection.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

def.p: surface-averaged heat flux from the hot wall (W/m2)
